questions.text: A 30 month old male child was brought with history of fever, and respiratory distress. Suspecting pneumonia , a chest xray was ordered. Which of the following is the most likely causative agent ? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Staphylococcus pneumoniae

 

Chest xray of child shows air filled cysts within lung parenchyma which are also known as pneumatoceles, and these are caused by staphylococcus pneumoniae.

 

Staphylococcus pneumoniae can cause primary or secondary pneumoniae (eg post influenza)

 

Clinical features – dyspnea, tachycardia, high fever, abdominal pain.

 

Staphylococcus aureus is also associated with complications like early development of empyema , pneumatocele , pyopneumothorax and bronchopleural fistula.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Klebsiella pneumoniae: While this organism can cause pneumonia, it is more commonly associated with pneumonia in adults with a characteristic "currant jelly" sputum and does not typically lead to pneumatocele formation.

 

Option B. Streptococcus pneumoniae: This is a common cause of bacterial pneumonia but typically does not cause pneumatoceles. It usually presents with lobar consolidation.

 

Option C. Mycoplasma pneumoniae: Often causes atypical pneumonia in older children and young adults, characterized by a more gradual onset of symptoms and a less severe clinical picture compared to bacterial pneumonia. Pneumatoceles are not a common feature.

 

Educational Objective:


Staphylococcus aureus can cause severe pneumonia in children, often complicated by the formation of pneumatoceles and other serious complications such as empyema and bronchopleural fistula.

questions.text: The patient presents with progressive breathlessness and chest pain for 2 days. The chest X-ray shows a radiolucent area in the left hemithorax with absent lung markings and shifted mediastinum. What will be the examination finding in the infra-scapular region? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hyperresonance on percussion

 

The patient's symptoms and chest X-ray findings are classic for tension pneumothorax. Key radiological features include a radiolucent hemithorax, absent lung markings, and mediastinal shift away from the affected side.

 

Hyperresonance on percussion is a characteristic finding in pneumothorax. This occurs because the pleural space is filled with air, which enhances sound transmission and creates an abnormally resonant percussion note compared to normal lung tissue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Coarse crackles: These adventitious sounds are heard in conditions with airway secretions or fluid, such as bronchiectasis or pulmonary edema, not in pneumothorax where air entry is absent.

 

Option C. Dull note on percussion: A dull note indicates fluid accumulation as seen in pleural effusion. In pneumothorax, the opposite finding of hyperresonance is present due to air accumulation.

 

Option D. Pleural rub: Pleural rub indicates inflammation of pleural surfaces. In pneumothorax, the pleural surfaces are separated by air, making a pleural rub impossible to appreciate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hyperresonance on percussion is a key clinical finding in pneumothorax, indicating the presence of air in the pleural space, and when combined with mediastinal shift suggests tension pneumothorax requiring immediate intervention.

questions.text: Which of the following set of values suggest primary hypothyroidism? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Low T4; High TSH

 

Primary hypothyroidism is a condition where the thyroid gland itself is not producing enough thyroid hormones (T4 and T3). This deficiency in thyroid hormone production leads to a decrease in circulating T4 levels. The pituitary gland responds to low T4 levels by increasing the secretion of thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) in an attempt to stimulate the thyroid gland to produce more thyroid hormones.

 

Thus, in primary hypothyroidism, the typical laboratory findings are:

 

  • Low T4: Indicates underproduction of thyroid hormone by the thyroid gland.
  • High TSH: Indicates the pituitary gland's response to low thyroid hormone levels by secreting more TSH to stimulate the thyroid gland.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Low T4; Low TSH: This pattern suggests secondary (or central) hypothyroidism, where the problem lies either in the pituitary gland (which produces TSH) or the hypothalamus (which produces TRH that stimulates TSH production). Both T4 and TSH are low because the pituitary gland is not secreting enough TSH to stimulate the thyroid gland.

 

Option C. High T4; High TSH: This pattern is indicative of central hyperthyroidism, where there is excessive production of TSH from the pituitary gland, leading to an overactive thyroid and high levels of T4.

 

Option D. High T4; Low TSH: This pattern suggests primary hyperthyroidism, where the thyroid gland is overactive and produces too much thyroid hormone, leading to high T4 levels. The pituitary gland responds by reducing TSH production.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primary hypothyroidism is characterized by low T4 levels and high TSH levels due to the thyroid gland's failure to produce sufficient thyroid hormones and the pituitary gland's compensatory increase in TSH secretion.

choices.text: Must be distinguished from Pulsus Alternans
Is a sign of digitalis toxicity

questions.text: All of the following statements about Pulsus Bigeminus are true, except? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Compensatory pause is absent

 

Explanation:

 

Pulsus bigeminus is characterized by a normal beat followed by a premature ventricular contraction (PVC), creating a pattern where every other beat appears weaker. This creates an alternating strong-weak pulse pattern. Importantly, PVCs typically have a compensatory pause following them, as the ventricle is refractory to the next normal sinus impulse.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Must be distinguished from Pulsus Alternans:  Pulsus bigeminus must be distinguished from pulsus alternans as they present differently. Pulsus alternans is associated with severe left ventricular dysfunction, while pulsus bigeminus is due to premature beats.

 

Option B. Is a sign of digitalis toxicity: Digitalis toxicity can produce various dysrhythmias including premature ventricular contractions in a bigeminal pattern. It's a classic manifestation of digoxin toxicity.

 

Option D. Rhythm is irregular: Pulsus bigeminus demonstrates an irregular rhythm with normal sinus beats interrupted by premature ventricular contractions.

 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Pulsus bigeminus is an irregular cardiac rhythm characterized by normal beats alternating with premature ventricular contractions, which are typically followed by compensatory pauses as the ventricle is refractory to the next sinus impulse.

questions.text:
What would be seen if the central part of the cord was involved? (INICET MAY 2022)

 

  1. LMN lesion of upper limbs and trunk and UMN of lower limbs.
  2. UMN lesion of upper limbs and trunk and LMN of lower limbs.
  3. Bladder and bowel involvement.
  4. Posterior tract involvement.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1 and 3

 

Central cord lesions, such as those seen in conditions like syringomyelia and intramedullary tumors, present with a distinct pattern of neurological deficits due to the anatomical arrangement of the spinal tracts.

 

1. LMN lesion of upper limbs and trunk and UMN of lower limbs: This pattern is common in central cord syndromes, where there is damage to the anterior horn cells leading to lower motor neuron (LMN) lesions in the upper limbs. As the condition progresses, upper motor neuron (UMN) signs may appear in the lower limbs due to the involvement of the corticospinal tract.

 

3. Bladder and bowel involvement: Central cord lesions can affect autonomic functions leading to bladder and bowel dysfunction, especially in cases of extensive or progressive lesions like intramedullary tumors.

 

Other Options:

 

2. UMN lesion of upper limbs and trunk and LMN of lower limbs: This pattern is not typical for central cord syndromes. Usually, the upper limbs show LMN signs due to the involvement of the anterior horn cells, and the lower limbs show UMN signs.

 

4. Posterior tract involvement: Posterior tracts, which carry fine touch, vibration, and proprioception, are usually spared in central cord syndromes. These tracts are located more dorsally in the spinal cord, away from the central lesion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Central cord lesions, such as syringomyelia, typically present with LMN signs in the upper limbs, UMN signs in the lower limbs, and can involve bladder and bowel dysfunction, but they do not typically affect the posterior tracts

questions.text: Epsilon wave is seen in: (NEET PG 2014)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Arrhythmogenic right ventricular dysplasia

 

Explanation:

 

Epsilon wave, also known as a “post-excitation wave,” is characteristic of Arrhythmogenic Right Ventricular Dysplasia (ARVD), also called Arrhythmogenic Right Ventricular Cardiomyopathy (ARVC). ARVD is an inherited cardiomyopathy characterized by fibro-fatty degeneration of the right ventricle, leading to recurrent ventricular arrhythmias originating from the right ventricle. The Epsilon wave appears as a terminal notch in the QRS complex and is due to slowed intra-ventricular conduction.

 

Triangle of Dysplasia:

 

ARVD typically involves three regions of the right ventricle known as the "triangle of dysplasia":

 

  1. Right Ventricular Outflow Tract (RVOT)
  2. Apex of the Right Ventricle
  3. Subtricuspid Region

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Brugada Syndrome: Characterized by a distinct ECG pattern (coved-type ST-segment elevation in V1-V3) and an increased risk of sudden cardiac death, but not associated with Epsilon waves.

 

Option B. Hypothermia: Hypothermia may produce Osborn waves (J waves) on ECG but not Epsilon waves.

 

Option C. WPW Syndrome: Characterized by the presence of a delta wave, which is a slurred upstroke in the QRS complex, indicative of pre-excitation due to an accessory pathway.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Epsilon waves are indicative of Arrhythmogenic Right Ventricular Dysplasia (ARVD) and appear as terminal notches in the QRS complex due to slowed intra-ventricular conduction.

choices.text: Aspirin & clopidogrel
Decompressive surgery
Mechanical thrombectomy

questions.text: A 53-year-old man was admitted with history of a cerebrovascular accident 2 days ago. The patient is drowsy with minimal response. CT findings is shown in the image below. What will be your next line of management? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Decompressive surgery

 

The CT scan image shows significant edema and midline shift affecting more than 50% of the Middle Cerebral Artery (MCA) territory. This extensive edema, along with the patient's low Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score, indicates severe brain swelling and increased intracranial pressure (ICP). In such cases, medical management alone (like mannitol for reducing ICP) may not be sufficient.

 

Guidelines for urgent decompression:

 

  • NIH Stroke scale > 15
  • Time < 48 hours
  • Age 18-60yrs
  • Territory infarct > 145cm3 or > 50% MCA territory
  • Informed consent that surgery improves survival but the patient may have significant disability.

 

Medical management of brain edema and increased intracranial pressure (ICP) may not be successful when significant swelling occurs in the cerebral or cerebellar hemisphere.

 

Therefore, a decompressive craniectomy should be considered to relieve the mass effect of the swollen cerebral or cerebellar hemisphere on the thalamus, brainstem and network projections to the cortex, which is manifested predominantly by decreased levels of arousal.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aspirin & clopidogrel: Incorrect as these medications are used for preventing further thrombotic events but are not suitable in the acute management of severe edema and brain shift.

 

Option B. Mannitol: Incorrect for sole use in this severe case, as it might not adequately control the mass effect and high ICP shown.

 

Option D. Mechanical thrombectomy: Incorrect because the primary issue in the CT image is the significant brain swelling and herniation risk, not an occlusion that can be resolved by thrombectomy at this stage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cases of significant cerebral edema with midline shift, as seen on CT in acute stroke settings, decompressive surgery is often necessary to prevent fatal outcomes and manage increased intracranial pressure effectively.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman presented with claudication in the forearm, transient loss of vision, and abdominal pain. Femoral pulses were weak. Fundus examination revealed retinal hemorrhages. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Takayasu arteritis

 

Takayasu arteritis, also known as "pulseless disease," is a large vessel vasculitis that primarily affects the aorta and its major branches. It is more common in young Asian females under 40 years old. The clinical presentation includes claudication (typically in the upper limbs due to subclavian artery involvement), weak pulses (particularly in the extremities), and symptoms resulting from ischemia in various organs (e.g., transient loss of vision due to carotid or vertebral artery involvement, abdominal pain due to mesenteric artery involvement).

 

The combination of weak femoral pulses, claudication in the forearm, and retinal hemorrhages is characteristic of Takayasu arteritis. This condition can lead to narrowing or occlusion of major arteries, causing diminished blood flow to the affected regions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Polyarteritis nodosa: Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) is a medium vessel vasculitis that can cause abdominal pain, claudication, and other systemic symptoms, but it does not typically affect the large vessels and therefore would not explain the weak femoral pulses. PAN is often associated with hepatitis B infection.

 

Option B. Thromboangiitis obliterans: Thromboangiitis obliterans (Buerger's disease) typically affects young male smokers and primarily involves the small and medium arteries of the extremities. It can cause claudication and ischemic symptoms in the limbs but does not typically cause weak femoral pulses or retinal hemorrhages.

 

Option D. Microscopic polyangiitis: Microscopic polyangiitis (MPA) is a small vessel vasculitis that often presents with symptoms related to kidney and lung involvement (e.g., rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis and pulmonary hemorrhage). It does not typically present with claudication or weak pulses in the large vessels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Takayasu arteritis should be considered in young women presenting with symptoms of large vessel occlusion, such as claudication, weak pulses, and ischemic symptoms in various organs. It is characterized by the involvement of the aorta and its major branches, and the diagnosis can be confirmed with imaging studies like CT angiogram or conventional angiography.

choices.text: ECG to rule out atrial fibrillation
If ECG is normal, CT scan should be done
Vestibular neuritis is a possible condition that can cause these symptoms

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presented with an episode of acute onset dizziness and loss of consciousness which lasted for a few seconds followed by a regain of full consciousness. There were no similar episodes in the past. Which of the following is a true statement regarding this scenario? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. ECG to rule out atrial fibrillation

 

An electrocardiogram (ECG) is crucial in the initial evaluation of a patient presenting with syncope, particularly to rule out cardiac causes such as atrial fibrillation, which can lead to episodic reductions in cardiac output and cerebral perfusion. Atrial fibrillation, a common arrhythmia in the elderly, can cause transient episodes of dizziness and loss of consciousness due to irregular and often rapid heart rate leading to ineffective heart pumping.

 

Note - In an elderly w/ first episode of syncope detailed history, clinical exam (cardiac, postural BP, neuro exam), basic investigations (ECG, +/- ECHO) is required

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. If ECG is normal, CT scan should be done: While a CT scan might be considered if there is suspicion of a neurological cause after a thorough clinical evaluation, it is not automatically the next step following a normal ECG, especially in the absence of neurological symptoms or signs suggestive of structural brain disease.

 

Option C. Tilt-table testing: This is generally reserved for cases where recurrent unexplained episodes of syncope occur, particularly when a vasovagal or orthostatic cause is suspected, not typically used after a first episode unless specific indications are present.

 

Option D. Vestibular neuritis is a possible condition that can cause these symptoms: Vestibular neuritis can cause severe vertigo and imbalance but typically does not cause loss of consciousness, making it less likely in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In elderly patients presenting with an acute onset of dizziness and syncope, an ECG is an essential first step to rule out arrhythmic causes such as atrial fibrillation. Additional diagnostic steps should be guided by the findings of the initial evaluation and specific clinical indicators.

 

Reference - Harrison 21/Atrial fibrillation/Chap 251

questions.text: A patient presented with dysphagia, vertigo, and facial numbness. Imaging showed cavitation in the medulla oblongata. What is the probable diagnosis? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Syringobulbia

 

Syringobulbia is characterized by the formation of a fluid-filled cavity (syrinx) within the brainstem, specifically affecting the medulla oblongata. The classic presentation includes lower cranial nerve symptoms such as dysphagia (IX, X nerves), vertigo (VIII nerve), and facial numbness (V nerve). The presence of cavitation in the medulla is pathognomonic for syringobulbia. This condition often causes asymmetric cranial nerve deficits due to the disruption of various nuclear groups within the medulla.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Brown-Sequard syndrome: This condition results from hemisection of the spinal cord, causing ipsilateral motor loss and proprioception loss with contralateral pain/temperature loss. It does not affect the brainstem or cause cranial nerve symptoms.

 

Option B. Tabes dorsalis: This late manifestation of neurosyphilis affects the dorsal columns of the spinal cord, causing proprioceptive loss and ataxia. It does not involve brainstem cavitation or cause cranial nerve dysfunction.

 

Option D. Syringomyelia: While related to syringobulbia, this condition involves cavitation of the spinal cord rather than the medulla. It typically presents with cape-like distribution of pain and temperature loss in the upper limbs, without cranial nerve involvement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Syringobulbia presents with lower cranial nerve symptoms (dysphagia, vertigo, facial numbness) and is characterized by cavitation within the medulla oblongata, distinguishing it from its spinal cord counterpart, syringomyelia.

questions.text: A patient had features of resting tremors, bradykinesia, and postural instability. He became bedridden and died due to respiratory failure. Brain biopsy is likely to show which of the following? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lewy bodies

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical features described (resting tremors, bradykinesia, and postural instability) are characteristic of Parkinson's disease.

 

In Parkinson's disease, the brain biopsy is likely to show Lewy bodies. Lewy bodies are intraneuronal, intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies made of aggregates of alpha-synuclein.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hirano bodies: Seen in Alzheimer's disease and other conditions like Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease and amyotrophic lateral sclerosis.

 

Option C. Guarnieri bodies: (Type B inclusion) Found in cells infected with poxvirus.

 

Option D. Negri bodies: Seen in the neurons of patients with rabies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Parkinson's disease, brain biopsies typically reveal Lewy bodies, which are intraneuronal, intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies made of alpha-synuclein.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with skin thickening muscle weakness and the peripheries becoming pale on exposure to cold. She is positive for ANA and anti-Scl-70 antibodies. Her creatinine kinase is elevated and muscle biopsy shows perifascicular infiltration. What is the antibody associated with this? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anti-PM-Scl antibody

 

The patient presents with features of scleroderma and dermatomyositis overlap syndrome. Anti-PM-Scl antibody is associated with this overlap syndrome, tends to produce nucleolar pattern in your ANA immunofluorescence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anti-U3 RNP: Associated with the diffuse form of scleroderma and are also known as anti-fibrillarin antibodies.
 

Option B. Anti-centromere antibody: Associated with limited scleroderma (CREST syndrome).
 

Option D. Anti-Jo-1 antibody: Associated with antisynthetase syndrome, which predominantly causes interstitial lung disease (ILD), mechanic's hands, myositis, and Raynaud's phenomenon. It is not associated with scleroderma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anti-PM-Scl antibody is associated with overlap syndromes involving scleroderma and myositis.

choices.text: Start antibiotics and send samples for culture

questions.text: A patient who is intubated had an X-ray done. The radiograph is shown below. What is the next step in the management of this patient? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ultrasound guided aspiration

 

Chest radiograph shows Unilateral Left pleural effusion. In the absence of suspicion for transudative effusion, thoracocentesis is indicated in this patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Suction with percussion physiotherapy is recommended in suspected collapse due to mucus plugging etc.

 

Option B. Antibiotics are initiated if suspicion of severe CAP is present.

 

Option C. Chest physiotherapy is given to reduce collapse and pulmonary rehabilitation.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Nothing, since CT was normal
Start on aspirin + clopidogrel
Advice BP control

questions.text: A patient presents with left-sided facial paralysis and weakness for the past 1 hour. Her blood pressure is 160/100 mmHg and CT shows dense MCA sign. What would be your next step? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Intravenous thrombolysis

 

The patient's presentation of acute left-sided facial paralysis and weakness, alongside the finding of a dense MCA (Middle Cerebral Artery) sign on a CT scan, indicates an acute ischemic stroke. The dense MCA sign is a radiologic indicator of a thrombus or embolus in the MCA, which is one of the most common sites for cerebral infarctions.

 

Given that the symptoms began only 1 hour ago and the CT has confirmed the location of the occlusion without showing any signs of hemorrhage or extensive infarction (which would contraindicate thrombolysis), intravenous thrombolysis is the most appropriate intervention. This treatment is aimed at dissolving the clot and restoring blood flow to the affected area of the brain.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nothing, since CT was normal: Incorrect because the CT was not normal; it showed a dense MCA sign, indicating an acute stroke.

 

Option B. Start on aspirin + clopidogrel: This would generally be considered in secondary prevention after the acute management phase of ischemic stroke, or if the patient was not a candidate for thrombolysis.

 

Option D. Advice BP control: While controlling blood pressure is important, it is not the immediate next step in the management of a patient showing signs of acute ischemic stroke with a window for thrombolysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of acute ischemic stroke with clear indications, intravenous thrombolysis should be administered as soon as possible within the therapeutic window to improve outcomes. Immediate evaluation and management are critical to maximize recovery and minimize long-term disability.

questions.text: Glucose load for screening diabetes in pregnancy is:  (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 75 gm

 

Explanation:

 

According to the majority of guidelines, including the WHO, IADPSG (International Association of Diabetes and Pregnancy Study Groups), and DIPSI (Diabetes in Pregnancy Study Group India) guidelines, a 75 gm glucose load is used for screening diabetes in pregnancy.

 

Note - The ACOG (American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists) guidelines follow a two-step process where the first step involves a 50 gm glucose load for screening, and if positive, a 100 gm glucose load for confirmation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 25 gm: Not used in any standard screening protocol.

 

Option B. 50 gm: Used in the initial step of the ACOG two-step screening process, but not the most common single-step screening load.

 

Option D. 100 gm: Used in the second step of the ACOG two-step screening process, not for initial screening.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For screening diabetes in pregnancy, the 75 gm glucose load is widely used according to various international guidelines, including WHO and IADPSG.

questions.text: A young donor came to the blood bank for the first time for platelet apheresis with platelet count of 1.9L. During the course he developed paraesthesia and circumoral numbness during donation. His vitals remained stable though. ECG showed tachycardia with ST-T changes. What is the reason for his symptoms? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hypocalcemia

 

Hypocalcemia occurs due to citrate. It is due to calcium binding citrate anticoagulant used to keep blood from clotting in apheresis machine.

 

Treatment for this would be to slow down the flow of device and/or giving oral calcium supplements.

 

IV calcium is only required in case of prolonged apheresis as in case of HPC collection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypovolemic Shock: This would be characterized by low blood pressure and signs of systemic shock, which are not described in this scenario.

 

Option C. Seizures: Although severe hypocalcemia can lead to seizures, the description focuses on paraesthesia and numbness, common early signs of hypocalcemia, without any mention of convulsive activity.

 

Option D. Allergic Reaction: The symptoms listed are not typical of allergic reactions, which might include hives, itching, or respiratory symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During platelet apheresis, monitoring for symptoms of hypocalcemia is crucial due to the use of citrate. Symptoms such as tingling, numbness, and ECG changes warrant immediate evaluation and management, typically with calcium supplementation to counteract the effects of citrate.

questions.text: Which of the following is an adverse effect associated with the long-term use of intermittent teriparatide for the treatment of osteoporosis? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Osteosarcoma

 

Teriparatide is a recombinant form of parathyroid hormone (PTH) used as an anabolic (bone-building) agent in the treatment of osteoporosis. It is administered via daily subcutaneous injections. While effective in increasing bone mass and reducing fracture risk, the long-term use of teriparatide has been associated with certain risks.

 

Osteosarcoma is a type of bone cancer that has been linked to the long-term use of teriparatide in animal studies. Specifically, when used for more than two years, there is evidence from these studies suggesting an increased risk of developing osteosarcoma. This potential risk has led to a restriction on the duration of teriparatide therapy to a maximum of two years.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Osteonecrosis of the jaw bone: This condition is a known adverse effect of bisphosphonates, not teriparatide. Bisphosphonates can lead to decreased blood flow to the jawbone, causing osteonecrosis, especially following dental procedures.

 

Option C. Subtrochanteric fracture (atypical femoral fracture): This type of fracture is also associated with long-term use of bisphosphonates, rather than teriparatide. Bisphosphonates may alter bone remodeling, leading to atypical fractures.

 

Option D. Loss of bone mass: Teriparatide is an anabolic agent that actually increases bone mass. Bisphosphonates also prevent bone mass loss by inhibiting osteoclast-mediated bone resorption. Thus, loss of bone mass is not associated with either teriparatide or bisphosphonates.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The long-term use of teriparatide is associated with an increased risk of osteosarcoma, which is why its use is limited to a maximum of two years.

choices.text: Increased activity of lipoprotein lipase and decreased activity of hormone sensitive lipase
Increased activity of hormone sensitive lipase and decreased lipoprotein lipase activity
Increase in peripheral function of LDL receptors
Increased in activity of hepatic lipase

questions.text: The value of TG and VLDL are high in chronic diabetes because of which of the following reasons: (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Increased activity of hormone sensitive lipase and decreased lipoprotein lipase activity.

 

In chronic diabetes, increase in hormone sensitive lipase and decrease in lipoprotein is seen, due to which values of TG and VLDL are increased.

 

Insulin has inhibitory effect on hormone sensitive lipase. In diabetes, low insulin corresponds to an increase in hormone sensitive lipase activity. This promotes breakdown of lipids and release of TG, and free fatty acids from the adipose tissue.

 

Insulin induces the activity of lipoprotein lipase, which is present on capillary walls. LPL promotes hydrolysis of TG and degradation of transport proteins, VLDL and chylomicrons. In diabetes, low insulin leads to decreased LPL activity which corresponds to increase in VLDL and TG.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased activity of lipoprotein lipase and decreased activity of hormone sensitive lipase: Incorrect because in diabetes, the activities of these enzymes are reversed; HSL activity is increased, and LPL activity is decreased.

 

Option C. Increase in peripheral function of LDL receptors: Incorrect because LDL receptor function generally affects LDL levels, not directly influencing VLDL or triglyceride levels.

 

Option D. Increased in activity of hepatic lipase: Incorrect for this context as hepatic lipase primarily affects the metabolism of HDL and to a lesser extent LDL, not directly impacting TG and VLDL levels in the way described for this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:


In chronic diabetes, the combination of increased hormone sensitive lipase activity (due to low insulin levels) and decreased lipoprotein lipase activity leads to higher levels of triglycerides and VLDL. This reflects the central role of insulin in lipid metabolism regulation.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man presents with dysphagia for solid foods more than liquid for the last 3 months and has severe cachexia. What will be the best investigation to establish the diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Upper GI Endoscopy with Biopsy

 

The patient's symptoms of dysphagia for solid foods more than liquids, coupled with severe cachexia, are highly suggestive of esophageal cancer.

 

Dysphagia for solids more than liquids typically indicates a structural problem in the esophagus. Upper GI endoscopy with biopsy is the best initial investigation to directly visualize the esophagus and obtain tissue samples for histopathological examination to confirm the diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Manometry: This is used to diagnose neuromuscular disorders of the esophagus, such as achalasia, but not typically used as the first-line investigation for suspected structural problems.

 

Option C. Barium swallow: This can provide imaging of the esophagus but is not as definitive as endoscopy with biopsy for diagnosing cancer.

 

Option D. CECT (Contrast-Enhanced CT): This is used for staging of cancer once the diagnosis is established but is not the primary diagnostic tool.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient with dysphagia predominantly for solids, especially with associated severe cachexia, upper GI endoscopy with biopsy is the best investigation to establish the diagnosis, often indicating esophageal cancer.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient presented with left-sided hemiparesis. Damage to which part of the internal capsule leads to this presentation? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Posterior limb

 

The internal capsule is a white matter structure in the brain that contains many important tracts, including those for motor and sensory functions. Damage to specific parts of the internal capsule can result in different clinical presentations based on the fibers that are affected.

 

Posterior limb is the part of the internal capsule that carries corticospinal and corticobulbar tracts, which are responsible for motor and sensory functions. Damage to the posterior limb can result in contralateral hemiparesis (weakness on the opposite side of the body). Therefore, a lesion in the posterior limb of the right internal capsule would lead to left-sided hemiparesis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Retrolentiform: This part of the internal capsule contains optic radiations, which are involved in visual processing. Damage here would lead to visual deficits rather than motor or sensory deficits.

 

Option B. Sublentiform: This part carries auditory radiations and is involved in hearing. Damage to this part would result in auditory deficits, not motor weakness.

 

Option C. Anterior limb: This part of the internal capsule contains frontopontine fibers and thalamocortical radiations, which are involved in cognitive and executive functions. Damage here might affect cognition but not typically result in hemiparesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Damage to the posterior limb of the internal capsule can lead to contralateral hemiparesis due to the involvement of motor and sensory pathways.

questions.text: Calculate the anion gap from the following values: Na+ = 137 mmol/L; K+ = 4 mmol/L; CI- =100 mmol/L; HCO3- = 15 mmol/L? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 22 mmol/L

 

AG = (Sum of cation) - (Sum of anion)

 

AG = (Na - (HCO3 + CL))

 

AG = 137 – 115 = 22 mmol/L

 

Note: Normal AG ~ 12

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following will not be measured to diagnose metabolic syndrome? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hip circumference


Metabolic syndrome criteria include: HDL levels, Blood glucose, Blood pressure and Waist circumference (NOT hip circumference)

 

Waist circumference - more than 102 centimeter in males or more than 88 centimeter in females is one of the important criteria for metabolic syndrome. Central obesity is a criterion for metabolic syndrome.

 

Other Options:


Option A. HDL levels: Low HDL levels (<40 mg/dL in males, <50 mg/dL in females) are a criterion for metabolic syndrome.

High triglyceride levels (>150 mg/dL) are a criterion for metabolic syndrome.


Option C. Blood glucose: Impaired glucose tolerance or type 2 diabetes is a criterion for metabolic syndrome.

 

Option D. Blood pressure: BP >140/90 mmHg or being hypertensive is a criterion for metabolic syndrome.

 

Note - To diagnose metabolic syndrome, the presence of at least three of these criteria is required.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hip circumference is not used in the diagnosis of metabolic syndrome; instead, waist circumference is measured.

questions.text: On performing a pulmonary function test, reduction in FEV1/FVC is characteristic of: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Obstructive disease

 

A reduction in the FEV1/FVC ratio (Forced Expiratory Volume in 1 second / Forced Vital Capacity) is characteristic of obstructive lung diseases. This ratio is a key indicator used to differentiate between obstructive and restrictive lung patterns on pulmonary function tests. In obstructive diseases, such as chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), asthma, and bronchiectasis, there is a disproportionate reduction in FEV1 relative to FVC due to airflow limitation and air trapping.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Restrictive disease: In restrictive lung diseases, both FEV1 and FVC are reduced proportionally, often leading to a normal or even increased FEV1/FVC ratio. Restrictive diseases include conditions such as pulmonary fibrosis and other interstitial lung diseases.

 

Option C. Normal lung function: Normal lung function would typically show an FEV1/FVC ratio within the normal range, which is generally above 0.7 in healthy adults.

 

Option D. Interstitial lung disease: This condition is a type of restrictive lung disease where there is a reduction in lung volumes, but the FEV1/FVC ratio is typically normal or increased, not reduced.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • FEV1/FVC reduction implies obstruction.
  • FEV1/FVC Increased or normal – Restrictive lung disease
  • Decrease in Maximum Mid-expiratory flow (MMEF) i.e., FEV25%-75% - Small airway disease

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT considered an extra glandular manifestation of Sjogren's syndrome? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Enlargement of both parotid glands

 

Explanation:

 

Enlargement of the parotid glands is one of the main glandular manifestations of Sjögren's syndrome, not an extra-glandular manifestation. Parotid gland enlargement occurs in about two-thirds of patients with primary Sjögren's syndrome due to lymphocytic infiltration of the gland. This is considered part of the primary exocrinopathy that characterizes the disease, alongside xerostomia (dry mouth) and keratoconjunctivitis sicca (dry eyes).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phenomenon of Raynaud: This is a true extra-glandular manifestation of Sjögren's syndrome, occurring in approximately 37% of patients. In one-third of patients, it precedes the sicca manifestations and is categorized as a non-specific extra-glandular feature.

 

Option B. Nephritis of the tubulointerstitial type: This is a genuine extra-glandular manifestation affecting 9% of Sjögren's syndrome patients. It is categorized as a peri-epithelial manifestation, typically asymptomatic, and results from lymphocyte accumulation around renal tubules.

 

Option D. Development of lymphoma: This is a serious extra-glandular manifestation occurring in approximately 6% of Sjögren's syndrome patients. Glandular MALT lymphoma is most common, with risk factors including persistent parotid enlargement, purpura, leukopenia, cryoglobulinemia, low C4 complement, and certain autoantibodies.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Sjögren's syndrome manifestations are classified as either glandular (involving exocrine glands like parotid, lacrimal, and salivary) or extra-glandular (affecting other organ systems including lungs, kidneys, vessels, and nervous system), with the latter occurring in about one-third of patients and determining disease severity.

questions.text: What is the most common presentation of inhalational anthrax? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hemorrhagic mediastinitis

 

Inhalational of anthrax spores (<5 microns) are phagocytosed by alveolar macrophages, carried to local mediastinal lymph nodes releasing toxins causing hemorrhagic mediastinitis

 

It is category A bioterrorism agent along with plague, botulism

 

Treatment recommended with IV antibiotics (Ciprofloxacin+Clindamycin)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Atypical pneumonia occurs in Chlamydia, Mycoplasma, Legionella pneumonia causing interstitial infiltrates

 

Option B. Lung abscess is seen as complication of infection with anaerobes, complication of pneumonia, atypical organisms like burkholderia, Infective endocarditis with septic embolism

 

Option D. Bronchopneumonia occurs due to pneumococcus, H.influenza etc.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hemorrhagic mediastinitis is the hallmark presentation of inhalational anthrax, indicating a severe systemic infection that requires immediate medical attention and aggressive antibiotic therapy. Awareness of this presentation is crucial, particularly in contexts involving potential exposure to anthrax spores, such as bioterrorism.

choices.text: Start ART if CD4 <200
Start ART and then ATT after 2 weeks
Start ATT and then ART after 2 weeks
Start ATT and ART simultaneously

questions.text: A newly diagnosed HIV patient presented with fever, cough, and hemoptysis. His sputum sample showed acid-fast bacilli. What is the appropriate management for this patient? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Start ATT and then ART after 2 weeks


In HIV patients with tuberculosis (TB), it is crucial to start antitubercular therapy (ATT) first to reduce the mycobacterial load before initiating antiretroviral therapy (ART). This approach helps to avoid immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome (IRIS), a life-threatening condition due to massive cytokine response triggered by a rapid increase in CD4 count., which can occur if ART is started too early. The general recommendation is to start ART by 2 weeks -2 months, after ATT initiation.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Starting ART only if CD4 <200: does not address the immediate need for TB treatment.

 

Option B. Starting ART before ATT: can lead to IRIS.

 

Option D. Starting both therapies simultaneously:  increases the risk of IRIS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In HIV patients with TB, start ATT first and then initiate ART after 2 weeks-2 months duration.

choices.text: Admit and give IV levofloxacin
Treat at home with oral Amox-clav
Admit and give IV ceftriaxone
Admit and give IV ceftriaxone and IV levofloxacin

questions.text: A 65-year-old man was brought after a fall. He has a fever and confusion. On examination, he had a cough with rales. The patient was also tachypneic. How will you manage this patient? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Admit and give IV ceftriaxone and IV levofloxacin

 

Explanation:

 

This patient is likely suffering from community-acquired pneumonia (CAP) and presents with confusion, fever, cough with rales, and tachypnea. Given his age (65 years) and symptoms, a CURB-65 score calculation is necessary. The CURB-65 score assigns points based on confusion, urea level, respiratory rate, blood pressure, and age ≥ 65. Here, the patient scores at least 3 points (confusion, tachypnea, age ≥ 65), indicating a need for hospital admission and potentially ICU care.

 

In managing CAP with a high CURB-65 score, empirical antibiotic therapy typically includes a combination of a beta-lactam (like ceftriaxone) and a macrolide or a respiratory fluoroquinolone (like levofloxacin). This combination is chosen to cover the most common pathogens, including Streptococcus pneumoniae and atypical bacteria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Admit and give IV levofloxacin: Levofloxacin alone is a potent respiratory fluoroquinolone but may not provide sufficient broad-spectrum coverage

 

Option B. Treat at home with oral Amox-clav: Given the patient's high CURB-65 score, home treatment is inappropriate. Oral antibiotics like Amox-clav are insufficient for severe CAP needing hospitalization.

 

Option C.  Admit and give IV ceftriaxone: While IV ceftriaxone is effective against many CAP pathogens, the addition of IV levofloxacin provides better coverage, especially for atypical organisms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In elderly patients with high CURB-65 scores and suspected severe community-acquired pneumonia, hospital admission and combination antibiotic therapy (such as IV ceftriaxone and IV levofloxacin) are essential for effective management.

questions.text: A 13-year-old girl went out playing. After coming home, she looked confused. Parents brought her to the hospital, and on examination, she looked irritable and has not passed urine since morning. Her friends said she had something while playing. Which of the following is the likely intoxication and the correct antidote? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Datura; Physostigmine

 

The clinical presentation suggests anticholinergic toxicity, characterized by confusion, irritability, and urinary retention. Datura, commonly known as jimsonweed or thorn apple, contains tropane alkaloids like atropine, scopolamine, and hyoscyamine, which cause anticholinergic symptoms.

 

Anticholinergic toxicity manifests with:

 

  • Central nervous system effects: confusion, hallucinations, irritability
  • Peripheral effects: dry mouth, urinary retention, constipation, tachycardia, hyperthermia

 

The appropriate antidote for anticholinergic toxicity is a cholinergic drug like physostigmine, which increases the levels of acetylcholine by inhibiting acetylcholinesterase.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Yellow oleander; Physostigmine: Yellow oleander poisoning involves cardiac glycosides similar to digoxin, which can cause bradycardia, hyperkalemia, and gastrointestinal symptoms. The antidote for oleander poisoning is Digibind, not physostigmine.

 

Option B. Datura; Digibind: While datura poisoning is correctly identified here, Digibind is the antidote for digoxin or digitalis toxicity, not anticholinergic toxicity caused by datura.

 

Option C. Yellow oleander; Digibind: This option correctly pairs yellow oleander poisoning with its antidote, Digibind. However, the clinical presentation does not fit yellow oleander poisoning, which typically involves bradycardia and gastrointestinal symptoms rather than confusion and urinary retention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Datura poisoning causes anticholinergic toxicity, characterized by confusion, urinary retention, and other anticholinergic symptoms. The antidote for such toxicity is physostigmine, a cholinergic agent that increases acetylcholine levels by inhibiting acetylcholinesterase.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presents with a fever. He is an intravenous drug user. On examination, a temperature of 38.5°C, and some spots can be noted over the fundus. CBC showed a leukocyte count of 20,000/cu mm. Blood has been sent for culture. Infective Endocarditis is suspected. How many minor Duke's Criteria are satisfied for the diagnosis? (FMGE July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 3

 

Explanation:

 

Duke's Criteria for the diagnosis of infective endocarditis include both major and minor criteria. In this case, the minor criteria that are satisfied include:

 

  1. Fever > 38°C: The patient has a fever of 38.5°C.
  2. Predisposing heart condition or intravenous drug use: The patient is an intravenous drug user.
  3. Immunologic phenomena: The presence of spots over the fundus suggests Roth spots, which are a form of immunologic phenomenon.

 

The other minor criteria –

 

  1. Vascular phenomena
  2. Blood culture is positive, but not meeting major criteria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1: Only fever would be counted.

 

Option B. 2: Fever and IV drug use would be counted.

 

Option D. 4: This would require additional minor criteria that are not mentioned in the question.

 

Additional Information -

 

Duke’s Major criteria for IE –

 

  • Blood culture persistently positive for typical microorganism ( ≥3 blood culture) from different puncture sides and gap between first and last culture should be atleast 1 hour: for diagnosis 2 out of 3 culture should be positive and for the same organism. Except Q fever -Coxiella Brunetti only single culture is enough.
  •  Imaging – Positive Echocardiogram – For IE specifically Transesophageal Echo – will show vegetation near the valves

 

Educational Objective:

 

In this case, three minor Duke's criteria are satisfied for the diagnosis of infective endocarditis: fever > 38°C, intravenous drug use, and immunologic phenomena (Roth spots).

questions.text: Which hormone increases during periods of stress, starvation, and deep sleep? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) GH

 

Growth Hormone (GH) is unique in that it increases during periods of stress, starvation, and deep sleep. GH plays a crucial role in growth, metabolism, and overall bodily repair and regeneration. During deep sleep, especially during slow-wave sleep, GH secretion peaks. This is vital for tissue growth and repair.

 

Stress and starvation also trigger the release of GH, which helps in mobilizing fat stores for energy and preserving muscle mass, among other functions. These adaptive responses are crucial for survival during periods of physical or emotional stress and food scarcity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glucocorticoids:  These hormones, which include cortisol, increase in response to stress and starvation. However, their levels typically decrease during deep sleep and peak in the early morning hours.

 

Option C. Cortisol:  A specific glucocorticoid that increases in response to stress and starvation, but like other glucocorticoids, its levels decrease during deep sleep and peak early in the morning.

 

Option D. Prolactin:  This hormone can increase in response to stress and has a role in metabolism and immune regulation, but it does not have the same peak during deep sleep as GH does.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Growth Hormone (GH) is the hormone that increases during periods of stress, starvation, and especially deep sleep, distinguishing it from other hormones that typically decrease during deep sleep.

questions.text: Which of the following hormone is released from zona fasciculata? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glucocorticoid

 

The adrenal cortex is divided into three zones, each responsible for producing different types of hormones. The mnemonic "GFR" can help remember the order and function of these zones:

 

  • Zona glomerulosa: Produces mineralocorticoids (e.g., aldosterone), which are involved in regulating salt and water balance.
  • Zona fasciculata: Produces glucocorticoids (e.g., cortisol), which play a key role in glucose metabolism, stress response, and immune function.
  • Zona reticularis: Produces androgens (e.g., dehydroepiandrosterone (DHEA) and androstenedione), which are precursors to sex hormones.

 

The zona fasciculata specifically secretes glucocorticoids, primarily cortisol, which is involved in various physiological processes including metabolism, immune response, and stress.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mineralocorticoid: This hormone is produced by the zona glomerulosa, not the zona fasciculata.

 

Option C. Androgen: These hormones are produced by the zona reticularis, not the zona fasciculata.

 

Option D. Adrenaline: This hormone is produced by the adrenal medulla, not the adrenal cortex.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The zona fasciculata of the adrenal cortex is responsible for producing glucocorticoids, mainly cortisol.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female complains of bone pain for 4 months. Her ALP levels are elevated, but serum calcium and phosphorus levels are normal, and X-ray of the patient is shown. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Paget's Disease

 

Paget's disease of bone is a chronic disorder that can result in enlarged and weakening of bones. The most commonly affected areas include the pelvis, skull, spine, and legs. In Paget's disease, the process of bone remodeling is disrupted, leading to an imbalance between the breakdown and formation of bone tissue. This results in the formation of structurally abnormal bone, which can cause pain, deformities, and an increased risk of fractures.

 

In this case, the patient presents with bone pain, elevated alkaline phosphatase (ALP) levels, and normal serum calcium and phosphorus levels, which are characteristic findings of Paget's disease. The X-ray showing multiple small spots and thickening of the calvarium is also typical of Paget's disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Osteosarcoma: Osteosarcoma is a type of bone cancer that typically affects younger individuals and presents with localized bone pain and swelling. It is associated with elevated ALP but usually involves more aggressive bone destruction and periosteal reaction on imaging.

 

Option C. Ewing's sarcoma: Ewing's sarcoma is a malignant bone tumor that commonly affects children and adolescents. It presents with pain and swelling and is associated with a characteristic "onion skin" appearance on X-ray. The patient's age and the X-ray findings do not support this diagnosis.

 

Option D. Osteochondroma: Osteochondroma is a benign bone tumor that usually presents as a painless, palpable mass near the ends of long bones in adolescents and young adults. It does not typically present with elevated ALP or the described X-ray findings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Paget's disease of bone is characterized by bone pain, elevated alkaline phosphatase levels, and normal serum calcium and phosphorus levels, with characteristic X-ray findings such as thickening of the calvarium

questions.text: A female patient with celiac disease is recommended a gluten-free diet. Which among the following can she consume?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Rice

 

Explanation:

 

Celiac disease requires a strict gluten-free diet to avoid triggering symptoms. Gluten is found in certain grains, specifically:

 

Mnemonic - BROW

 

  • Barley
  • Rye
  • Oats (unless specifically labeled gluten-free due to potential cross-contamination)
  • Wheat

 

Rice is naturally gluten-free and safe for consumption by individuals with celiac disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wheat: Contains gluten and must be avoided.

 

Option B. Barley: Contains gluten and must be avoided.

 

Option C. Oats: Often contaminated with gluten unless specifically labeled gluten-free and should be avoided unless confirmed to be safe.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Individuals with celiac disease should avoid wheat, barley, rye, and oats unless specifically labelled gluten-free, while rice is a safe option.

questions.text: Mill wheel murmur is seen in: (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pneumopericardium

 

Mill wheel murmur (also known as "bruit de moulin") is a characteristic splashing sound heard on cardiac auscultation in cases of pneumopericardium. This sign occurs due to the presence of both air and fluid within the pericardial space, creating a churning sound with cardiac motion, similar to the sound of a water wheel. The sound is best heard when the patient is in the left lateral decubitus position.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pneumoperitoneum: This refers to air in the peritoneal cavity, typically due to hollow viscus perforation. While it can produce succussion splash with movement, it does not create a cardiac-related murmur.

 

Option C. Pneumomediastinum: This condition presents with Hamman's sign (crunching sound synchronous with heartbeat) but not a mill wheel murmur, as there is only air (no fluid) in the mediastinal space.

 

Option D. Hydropneumothorax: While this condition has both air and fluid in the pleural space and can produce succussion splash with movement, it does not create a characteristic cardiac murmur like the mill wheel murmur.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mill wheel murmur is a specific clinical sign heard in cases of pneumopericardium with fluid (hydro pneumopericardium), characterized by a churning or splashing sound due to the presence of both air and fluid in the pericardial space.

questions.text: Gastric antral vascular ectasia is responsible for which of the following appearances? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Watermelon stomach.

 

Explanation:

 

Gastric antral vascular ectasia (GAVE) is characterized by its distinctive endoscopic appearance resembling the stripes of a watermelon, hence the name "watermelon stomach." This condition features linear red streaks arranged in a radial pattern around the antrum of the stomach. These streaks represent dilated mucosal blood vessels that can cause chronic blood loss and iron deficiency anemia. GAVE is often associated with certain systemic conditions including portal hypertension, autoimmune disorders, and chronic renal failure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Washerman stomach: This is not a recognized term for any specific gastric endoscopic finding. It does not describe the appearance of gastric antral vascular ectasia.

 

Option C. Windmill stomach: This is not a recognized term in gastroenterology for describing the appearance of gastric lesions or vascular abnormalities.

 

Option D. Windshield stomach: This is not a recognized term for any specific gastric endoscopic finding. It is not used to describe gastric antral vascular ectasia or any other known gastric condition.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Gastric antral vascular ectasia produces a characteristic endoscopic appearance called "watermelon stomach" with red stripes resembling a watermelon, representing dilated blood vessels that can cause chronic blood loss.

questions.text: A 46-year-old male presents to the ER with the acute onset of ataxia. Neurological examination shows loss of pain and temperature sensation from the face on the left side and loss of pain and temperature sensation from the right half of the body. He also has dysarthria, dysphagia, and diminished gag reflex with ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis on the left. What is the most likely diagnosis? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Lateral medullary syndrome

 

The patient's presentation with loss of pain and temperature sensation from the left side of the face and the right side of the body, along with dysarthria, dysphagia, and diminished gag reflex, suggests involvement of the lateral medulla. Additionally, the presence of Horner's syndrome (ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis) on the left side further supports this diagnosis.

 

Lateral medullary syndrome, also known as Wallenberg syndrome, typically results from occlusion of the vertebral artery or the posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA). The key clinical features include:

 

  • Ipsilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation in the face due to involvement of the spinal trigeminal nucleus.
  • Contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation in the body due to involvement of the spinothalamic tract.
  • Dysarthria and dysphagia due to involvement of the nucleus ambiguus (cranial nerves IX and X).
  • Ipsilateral Horner's syndrome due to disruption of the descending sympathetic pathways.
  • Ataxia due to involvement of the inferior cerebellar peduncle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lateral pontine syndrome: Lateral pontine syndrome involves the pons and typically affects cranial nerves that are not involved in this patient's presentation. For example, it often involves the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII), leading to facial weakness, which is not described in this case.

 

Option B. Medial medullary syndrome: Medial medullary syndrome affects the medial structures of the medulla, including the hypoglossal nerve (cranial nerve XII), and results in ipsilateral tongue weakness and contralateral hemiparesis. This does not match the patient's symptoms.

 

Option D. Locked-In Syndrome: Locked-In Syndrome results from bilateral lesions in the ventral pons, leading to quadriplegia and anarthria, but with preserved consciousness and vertical eye movements. The patient's symptoms do not align with this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lateral medullary syndrome (Wallenberg syndrome) is characterized by ipsilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation in the face, contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation in the body, dysarthria, dysphagia, and ipsilateral Horner's syndrome.

choices.text: Oral glucose challenge test with GH level
Insulin like growth factor 1 binding potein -3 (IGFBP-3 )
Insulin like growth factor -1 levels
Random growth hormone levels

questions.text: A 44 yr old man is referred to your center for management of severe hyperglycemia. During examination, you note that patient has enlarged feet, coarse facial features, and prognathism. You suspect acromegaly. Which of the following tests can you use as a screening method for this condition ? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Insulin like growth factor-1 levels

 

Acromegaly is a clinical syndrome that results from excessive secretion of growth hormone (GH). Produced mainly in the pituitary gland, GH controls the physical growth of the body. In adults, too much of this hormone causes bones, cartilage, body organs, and other tissues to increase in size. Acromegaly is most often diagnosed in middle-aged adults, but symptoms can appear at any age. In children, too much growth hormone causes a condition called gigantism rather than acromegaly.

 

Best screening test for acromegaly is serum insulin like growth factor-1 (IGF-1).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oral glucose challenge test with GH level: While this test is used to diagnose acromegaly by demonstrating a lack of GH suppression after glucose administration, it is more complex and typically performed after IGF-1 screening suggests acromegaly.

 

Option B. Insulin-like growth factor 1 binding protein-3 (IGFBP-3): Although IGFBP-3 levels are influenced by GH, they are not routinely used for screening acromegaly.

 

Option D. Random growth hormone levels: These levels can fluctuate significantly throughout the day and are influenced by various factors, making random GH levels unreliable for diagnosing acromegaly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Serum IGF-1 is the preferred initial test for screening acromegaly due to its reliability and the persistence of elevated levels in the presence of excessive GH production. This test provides a stable indicator of disease activity and is less variable than direct GH measurements.

questions.text: A patient with diabetes develops a UTI, which gets complicated with hypotension that is resistant to IV fluids. Which of the following antibiotics can be used? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Piperacillin-Tazobactam

 

The patient with diabetes has developed a urinary tract infection (UTI) complicated by hypotension resistant to IV fluids, indicating septic shock. In cases of septic shock, it is critical to start with empirical broad-spectrum antibiotics. These antibiotics are designed to cover a wide range of potential pathogens until the specific causative organism can be identified and targeted.

 

Broad-spectrum antibiotics suitable for such severe infections include:

 

  • Piperacillin-Tazobactam
  • Carbapenems like Meropenem or Imipenem
  • Certain third-generation cephalosporins like Ceftazidime

 

In this case, Piperacillin-Tazobactam is chosen because it is a broad-spectrum antibiotic that covers many of the common pathogens responsible for severe infections and septic shock. Although a combination of Meropenem with Vancomycin would be ideal, the given options do not include Meropenem. Therefore, Piperacillin-Tazobactam is the best choice among the provided options.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Amoxicillin-Clavulanate: This antibiotic is generally not sufficient for treating severe infections or septic shock due to its narrower spectrum of activity compared to Piperacillin-Tazobactam.

 

Option C. Ceftriaxone: While Ceftriaxone is a third-generation cephalosporin, it is not as broad-spectrum as Ceftazidime and does not provide the same coverage needed for septic shock.

 

Option D. Nitrofurantoin: This antibiotic is typically used for uncomplicated lower urinary tract infections and is not effective for severe systemic infections or septic shock.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the management of septic shock, especially in a patient with diabetes and complicated UTI, broad-spectrum antibiotics such as Piperacillin-Tazobactam are critical for empirical therapy.

questions.text: A 76-year-old man presented with generalized weakness, which increased towards the evening and improved with 5-10 minutes of rest in between. On examination, he also had ptosis and some difficulty in swallowing. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Myasthenia Gravis

 

Myasthenia Gravis (MG) is characterized by fluctuating muscle weakness and fatigability, which typically worsens with activity and improves with rest. The hallmark of MG is weakness that is more pronounced towards the end of the day or after prolonged activity, and this weakness improves after a period of rest.

 

Key features in this patient’s presentation include:

 

  • Generalized weakness that increases in the evening.
  • Improvement in weakness with short rest periods.
  • Presence of ptosis (drooping eyelids) and difficulty in swallowing, which are common manifestations of MG.

 

In MG, autoantibodies attack the acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction, impairing neuromuscular transmission. This leads to the characteristic symptoms of fluctuating weakness and fatigability.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lambert Eaton Myasthenic Syndrome: Lambert Eaton Myasthenic Syndrome (LEMS) is a paraneoplastic syndrome often associated with small cell lung cancer. It also involves muscle weakness but typically improves with exercise rather than worsening, which is opposite to the pattern seen in MG.

 

Option C. Peripheral Neuropathy: Peripheral neuropathy generally presents with sensory disturbances, weakness, and diminished reflexes in a stocking-glove distribution. It does not typically cause fluctuating weakness or specific muscle group involvement such as ptosis.

 

Option D. Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy: Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy (DMD) is a genetic disorder that presents in early childhood with progressive muscle weakness, particularly in the proximal muscles. It is highly unlikely to present in a 76-year-old man as it typically leads to severe disability or death by early adulthood.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myasthenia Gravis is characterized by fluctuating muscle weakness that worsens with activity and improves with rest. Key clinical features include ptosis, difficulty swallowing, and generalized weakness with a diurnal variation.

 

Most sensitive diagnosis is supported by single fiber EMG and most specific investigation is antibody tests, such as acetylcholine receptor antibodies and anti-muscle specific kinase antibodies.

questions.text: Which of the following rules out transudative pleural effusion except? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) High fibrin

 

Explanation:

 

Transudative pleural effusions are typically characterized by low protein, low specific gravity, and low cellular content. High fibrin content, on the other hand, is suggestive of an exudative effusion rather than a transudative one.

 

Differentiating features:

 

 

 

Additional information

 

Light's criteria: These are used to differentiate exudative pleural effusions from transudative effusions based on the chemical and cellular characteristics of the pleural fluid.

 

  1. Protein Ratio: If the ratio of the protein content in the pleural effusion to the serum protein is more than 0.5 (or 50%), the effusion is likely an exudate.
  2. LDH Ratio: If the lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) level in the effusion is more than 60% (or 0.6) of the serum LDH, it indicates that the effusion is likely an exudate.
  3. LDH Upper Limit: If the LDH level in the effusion exceeds two-thirds of the upper limit of normal for serum LDH as defined by the laboratory, the effusion is likely an exudate.

 

If, any one out of three criteria is positive, then its an exudate

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Low protein: This is a feature of transudative effusions.

 

Option C. Low specific gravity: This is also a characteristic of transudative effusions.

 

Option D. Low cellular content: This is another feature seen in transudative effusions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

High fibrin content in pleural fluid is indicative of an exudative effusion, which rules out the diagnosis of a transudative pleural effusion.

choices.text: Decrease in Systolic blood pressure 20 mmHg after 6 mins of standing
Decrease in Diastolic blood pressure 20 mmHg after 6 mins of standing
Decrease in Systolic blood pressure 20 mmHg after 3 min of standing
Decrease in diastolic blood pressure 20 mmHg after 3 mins of standing

questions.text: True about the definition of Postural Hypotension: (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Decrease in systolic blood pressure 20 mm Hg after 3 mins of standing

 

“3-20-10” mnemonic can aid in remembering the definition of orthostatic hypotension.

 

Sustained fall of SBP > 20mmHg /DBP > 10mmHg after 3 mins of standing. Usually, it is accompanied by a rise in HR. Absence of increase in heart rate suggest neurogenic/autonomic dysfunction.

 

Cause of Orthostatic Hypotension:

 

  • Cardiac pump failure
  • Hypovolemia
  • Endocrinopathies: AI, Pheochromocytoma.
  • Venous pooling
  • Medications

 

Other Options:

 

Option A and B: These options extend the timing to 6 minutes, which is not standard for the initial assessment of orthostatic hypotension.

 

Option D: Specifies a diastolic drop which should be 10 mmHg, not 20 mmHg, thus making it incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Postural hypotension, also known as orthostatic hypotension, is defined as a significant drop in blood pressure when a person stands up from a sitting or lying position. The correct definition, as per the consensus, includes a decrease in systolic blood pressure of 20 mmHg or a decrease in diastolic blood pressure of 10 mmHg within 3 minutes of standing. The answer C correctly reflects the component of this definition regarding the systolic blood pressure drop.

 

Reference - Harrison/Cardiology, chap 21/695

questions.text: Which of the following is not a common feature of ABPA? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Distal bronchiectasis

 

ABPA is diagnosed based on ISHAM criteria which requires the following:

  1. Predisposing Condition: Asthma/Cystic fibrosis
  2. Mandatory Criteria:
    • Serum IgE > 1000 IU/mL
    • Aspergillus specific IgE >0.35kU/L(OR) +ve skin test against A. fumigatus. (Test indicates sensitization/Type1 HSN reaction)
  3. Supportive Criteria (≥2 should be present):
    • Total eosinophil > 500 cells/mm3
    • Aspergillus specific IgG
    • Radiology Typical for ABPA
      • Central and proximal cylindrical bronchiectasis
      • Alterations predominantly in the upper lobe
      • Nodules
      • Atelectasis
      • Air trapping

 

Note: HAM (High attenuation mucus) is pathognomonic feature of ABPA on HRCT

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cough: Cough is a typical symptom of ABPA, resulting from airway inflammation and response to mucus production.

 

Option C. Wheezing: Wheezing in ABPA is due to airway obstruction caused by mucus plugging and inflammation.

 

Option D. Raised serum IgE levels: Elevated IgE levels are a hallmark of ABPA, reflecting the immune system’s hypersensitivity reaction to Aspergillus.

 

Educational Objective:


Central and proximal bronchiectasis, not distal bronchiectasis, is a characteristic radiological finding in ABPA, helping to differentiate it from other pulmonary conditions. The presence of cough, wheezing, and significantly raised serum IgE levels are supportive of the diagnosis.

 

Reference: Harrison 21/Pulmonary infiltrates with eosinophilia/Chap 288

questions.text: What percentage of increase in FEV1 represents the minimum change required to demonstrate the reversibility of obstruction after administration of bronchodilators in bronchial asthma?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) > 12%

 

Explanation:

 

To diagnose bronchial asthma, it is essential to demonstrate the reversibility of airway obstruction. This is typically assessed by measuring the increase in FEV1 (Forced Expiratory Volume in 1 second) after the administration of a bronchodilator.

 

The criteria for significant reversibility in FEV1 are:

 

  • An increase in FEV1 of more than 12% from the baseline.
  • An absolute increase in FEV1 of more than 200 ml.

 

These criteria confirm that the obstruction is reversible, which is a hallmark of asthma.

 

Note - Criterion is used for assessing peak flow rate (PFR) variability is > 20%.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A minimum increase of more than 12% in FEV1 after bronchodilator administration is required to demonstrate the reversibility of airway obstruction in bronchial asthma.

questions.text: A young man came to the medical OPD with complaints of early morning backache and stiffness, which improves on exercise, and persistent red eyes. On examination, lung expansion was less than 3 cm. X-ray is shown in the image given below. What is the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ankylosing spondylitis

 

Ankylosing spondylitis (AS) is a chronic inflammatory disease that primarily affects the spine and sacroiliac joints, leading to pain and stiffness. The hallmark feature of AS is inflammatory back pain, which is characterized by pain and stiffness that are worse in the morning and improve with exercise. The persistent red eyes are indicative of anterior uveitis, a common extra-articular manifestation of AS.

 

The reduced lung expansion (less than 3 cm) points towards involvement of the thoracic spine, leading to restrictive lung disease due to reduced chest wall mobility. The X-ray image shows characteristic changes of AS, including syndesmophytes and the "bamboo spine" appearance, which result from the ossification of ligaments and entheses (where tendons and ligaments attach to the bone).

 

Bamboo spine

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Paget's disease: This condition is characterized by abnormal bone remodeling but does not typically present with inflammatory back pain or extra-articular manifestations such as uveitis.

 

Option C. Healed tuberculosis: While tuberculosis can affect the spine (Pott's disease), it does not present with the classic inflammatory back pain or the characteristic radiographic changes seen in AS.

 

Option D. Osteopetrosis: This is a rare genetic disorder that leads to increased bone density and brittleness but does not present with the clinical and radiographic features of AS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ankylosing spondylitis should be suspected in young patients with inflammatory back pain that improves with exercise, reduced lung expansion, and extra-articular manifestations such as uveitis. The "bamboo spine" on X-ray is a characteristic finding in advanced cases of AS.

questions.text:
Which of the following are signs of Superior Vena Cava Syndrome? (Twisted PYQ)

  1. Non-pulsatile rise of JVP
  2. Orthopnea
  3. Facial edema
  4. Prominent chest wall collaterals
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 3, 4

 

Superior Vena Cava Syndrome (SVCS) presents with characteristic signs due to obstruction of venous return from the upper body. The following signs are indicative of SVCS:

 

1. Non-pulsatile rise of JVP : This is a classic finding in SVC obstruction as the venous congestion prevents normal cardiac pulsations from being transmitted.

 

3. Facial edema : Occurs due to impaired venous drainage from the head and neck region.

 

4. Prominent chest wall collaterals : Develops as alternate pathways for venous return, visible as dilated superficial veins on the chest wall.

 

Other Option:

 

Option 2 (Orthopnea): This is incorrect as orthopnea is primarily associated with left heart failure. While SVCS patients may have breathing difficulties, true orthopnea is not a characteristic feature.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Superior Vena Cava Syndrome is characterized by the triad of non-pulsatile JVP elevation, facial edema, and prominent chest wall collaterals, reflecting obstruction to upper body venous return.

questions.text: What does the ECG show? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) P mitrale

 

The ECG shows broad, notched P waves (>0.12 seconds) in lead II with a "dome and spike" or "M-shaped" configuration, which is characteristic of P mitrale. This finding indicates left atrial enlargement, commonly seen in mitral valve disease. The widened, notched P wave occurs due to delayed left atrial activation and increased left atrial size, typically when left atrial pressure or volume is increased. This pattern is particularly prominent in lead II and V1, where V1 often shows a prominent terminal negative deflection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Electrical alternans: This refers to beat-to-beat variation in QRS complex amplitude or axis, typically seen in pericardial effusion. The ECG shows consistent P wave abnormalities rather than alternating patterns.

 

Option B. P pulmonale: While this also represents atrial enlargement, P pulmonale shows tall (>2.5mm) and peaked P waves without widening or notching, indicating right atrial enlargement. The current ECG shows wide, notched P waves characteristic of left atrial enlargement.

 

Option D. Improper calibration: This would affect all ECG waves uniformly rather than showing specific P wave morphology changes. The consistent nature of the P wave abnormality rules out calibration issues.

 

Educational Objective:

 

P mitrale, characterized by broad (>0.12s), notched P waves in lead II with a "dome and spike" configuration, indicates left atrial enlargement, commonly associated with mitral valve disease or other conditions causing left atrial pressure or volume overload.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male patient has been diagnosed with hypertension. On examination, there is no existing cardiovascular disease, no hypertension-mediated organ damage (HMOD), and the renal function is normal. He should be immediately started on pharmacological management if his blood pressure is more than: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. > 160/100 mmHg

 

  • The ISH (International society of HTN) 2020 guidelines were made to help decision making in low-middle income countries.
  • Presence of ASCVD risk factors, HMOD (HTN mediated organ damage) is an indication to start anti-HTN therapy.
  • Home BP recording helps in diagnosis of Masked HTN, rule out white-coat effect
  • ABPM provides 24-hour trend and fluctuations in BP.

 

 

Home BP > 135/85 mmHg = HTN

 

ABPM cutoffs:

 

  1. Mean Awake (daytime) average ≥ 135/85 mmHg
  2. 24h average ≥ 130/80 mmHg
  3. Mean Asleep(night) ≥ 120/70 mmHg

 

BP drops at night by (10-20%), morning surge – Steep increase, peaks in late afternoon.
 

Best observed in ABPM (Ambulatory BP monitoring):

 

  • Normal Dip: 10-20 % at night
  • Extreme Dip > 20%
  • Non-dippers < 10% (A/w Activation of RAAS)
  • Risers: BP raise

 

Note: Increase mortality risk among Non-Dippers and Risers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Immediate pharmacological treatment for hypertension in patients without additional cardiovascular risk factors or organ damage should commence when blood pressure levels exceed 160/100 mmHg, according to the ISH 2020 guidelines. This approach helps to target treatment to those most likely to benefit from immediate intervention, balancing the benefits and risks of pharmacotherapy.

 

Reference: ISH2020, AHA2017 HTN guidelines

questions.text: Which among the following is wrong about DIC? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
