questions.solution:
Ans. C) Increased fibrinogen

 

Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation (DIC) is a complex condition characterized by systemic activation of blood clotting, which results in the generation and deposition of fibrin, leading to microvascular thrombi in various organs and contributing to multiple organ dysfunction syndrome. As a part of this process, there is widespread consumption of clotting factors and platelets, which leads to a paradoxical increase in bleeding risk.

 

  • Increased fibrinogen is incorrect because in DIC, fibrinogen is typically decreased, not increased. This decrease is due to its consumption during the formation of fibrin clots throughout the body.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 30% of patients w/DIC may have schistocytes on PS.

 

Option B. Consumption of clotting factors leads to ↑PT, aPTT. Presence of normal PT, aPTT w/schistocytes hints towards possibility of MAHA.

 

Option D. FDP are elevated due to activation of coagulation cascade.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In DIC, one typically sees a constellation of laboratory findings including decreased fibrinogen, increased PT and aPTT, elevated FDPs, and the presence of schistocytes on peripheral blood smear. These changes reflect both the excessive activation of the coagulation cascade and the secondary activation of fibrinolytic pathways, leading to the consumption of clotting factors and secondary bleeding complications.

 

Reference - Harrison/Hematology/Coagulation disorders

choices.text: 2-3 L of normal saline over 1-3 hours
Insulin infusion at 0.1 units/kg/hour
Insulin bolus of 0.1 units/kg given IV

questions.text: A 12-year-old child who is known to have type 1 diabetes mellitus presents with confusion and drowsiness. Her mother says that she seems to be breathing very fast. On examination, mucous membranes are dry and blood pressure is 70/50 mm Hg. Random blood glucose is 415 mg/dL and urine ketones are 4+. What is the next best step in management? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 2-3 L of Normal saline over 1-3 hours

 

IV fluids are the next best management as the patient is in shock and needs immediate correction. ABG here could show HAGMA secondary to type A lactic acidosis or ketoacidosis. Hence, ABG wouldn’t help in the diagnosis here. Shock in patient with DKA is not common and suggest an underlying sepsis as excess glucotoxicity causes shift of H2O to the intravascular compartment. IV fluid bolus is given in the emergency immediately.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Insulin infusion at 0.1 units/kg/hour: While insulin therapy is critical in the management of DKA, it should only be started after initial fluid resuscitation has been commenced and any electrolyte imbalances, particularly potassium, have been assessed and addressed.

 

Option C. Arterial blood gas: While ABG can provide valuable information about the severity of acidosis and help guide management, it is not the immediate next step before ensuring adequate fluid resuscitation.

 

Option D. Insulin bolus of 0.1 units/kg given IV: An insulin bolus can potentially exacerbate hypokalemia in the setting of DKA. Fluid resuscitation and stabilization should precede any insulin bolus or infusion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a case of DKA presenting with signs of dehydration and shock, the initial management should focus on aggressive fluid resuscitation to stabilize the patient before initiating insulin therapy. This approach not only addresses the immediate life-threatening condition but also prepares the body for further metabolic correction.

 

Reference - Harrison 21E/DKA/Chapter 404

questions.text: Which among the following drugs decreases the serum parathyroid hormone levels? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Calcitriol

 

Calcitriol is the active form of vitamin D and plays a crucial role in calcium and phosphate metabolism in the body. It directly acts on vitamin D receptors (VDRs) present in the parathyroid gland, leading to a decrease in the secretion of parathyroid hormone (PTH).

 

Mechanism of Action: Calcitriol increases the absorption of calcium and phosphate from the intestines. Elevated levels of calcium in the blood provide negative feedback to the parathyroid glands, which reduces the production of PTH. Additionally, calcitriol directly inhibits the synthesis and secretion of PTH by binding to VDRs in the parathyroid gland. This dual action ensures a reduction in PTH levels, making calcitriol an effective treatment for conditions associated with secondary hyperparathyroidism.

 

Note - Paricalcitol: A synthetic vitamin D receptor (VDR) agonist used to reduce PTH levels in primary hyperparathyroidism. This drug is related to the Cinacalcet, a calcium sensitizer but this act on the calcium-sensing receptor (CaSR).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Risedronate: Risedronate is a bisphosphonate used to treat osteoporosis. It works by inhibiting osteoclast-mediated bone resorption, which can sometimes lead to hypocalcemia. Hypocalcemia can reflexively increase PTH levels, rather than decrease them.

 

Option C. Lithium: Lithium is known to cause unexplained hyperparathyroidism and consequently increase PTH levels. It is one of the common causes of unexplained hyperparathyroidism, making it an unsuitable option for decreasing PTH levels.

 

Option D. Diuretics: Diuretics, particularly loop diuretics, can cause hypocalcemia, which in turn can lead to an increase in PTH levels. Thiazide diuretics can cause hypercalcemia, which might decrease PTH levels, but in this question, "diuretics" is mentioned generally, and loop diuretics are more commonly associated with increased PTH levels due to hypocalcemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Calcitriol, the active form of vitamin D, decreases serum parathyroid hormone levels by increasing calcium absorption from the intestines and directly inhibiting PTH secretion from the parathyroid glands through its action on vitamin D receptors.

questions.text: What is the diagnostic test of choice for HIV in a baby born to an HIV-infected mother? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. HIV DNA PCR
 

Maternal antibodies transferred passively to the infant may persist 9-18 months and hence ELISA/antibody tests positivity would indicate possible exposure to HIV.

 

Currently NACO recommends HIV-TNA PCR (Total nucleic acid = pro-viral DNA + RNA) which has Sensitivity of 99% and Specificity of 98% in infants < 18 months of age.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. DBS (Dried blood sample) is recommended and not CORD BLOOD (as it contains maternal blood contamination).

 

Option C. Western blot is not recommended by NACO for the diagnosis of HIV.

 

Option D. ELISA based test detects antibodies, however, maternal transmission occurs in infants trans placentally and hence cannot help in diagnosis of active disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For infants born to HIV-infected mothers, HIV DNA PCR is the preferred diagnostic test because it detects viral DNA directly, avoiding the pitfalls of tests that detect antibodies, which may not distinguish between maternal antibodies and those produced by the infant itself.

 

Reference: NACO 2021 HIV Care and treatment guidelines Page 185

questions.text: A diabetic elderly man presents with dyspnea and pedal edema. A chest X-ray (CXR) shows an enlarged heart with rales. Echo reveals a low ejection fraction (EF). Which of the following treatments will delay the progression of cardiac disease? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Empagliflozin

 

Empagliflozin is a medication that belongs to the class of sodium-glucose co-transporter-2 (SGLT2) inhibitors. Although it is primarily used to manage diabetes by promoting glucose excretion through urine, it has been found to have significant benefits in patients with heart failure, particularly those with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF).

 

Mechanism of Action in Heart Failure: Empagliflozin improves cardiac outcomes through several mechanisms:

 

  • Reduction in preload and afterload: By promoting diuresis and natriuresis, empagliflozin reduces the volume overload, which is beneficial in heart failure.
  • Improvement in myocardial metabolism: It shifts myocardial substrate utilization from glucose to ketone bodies, which is more energy-efficient for the failing heart.
  • Reduction in cardiac fibrosis and inflammation: Empagliflozin has anti-inflammatory and anti-fibrotic effects, which help in reducing cardiac remodeling and progression of heart failure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hydrochlorothiazide: This is a thiazide diuretic primarily used to manage hypertension and mild fluid retention. However, it does not have significant benefits in delaying the progression of heart failure.

 

Option C. Furosemide: Furosemide is a loop diuretic used for symptomatic relief of fluid overload in heart failure but does not specifically alter the progression of the disease.

 

Option D. Digoxin: Digoxin is used in heart failure to improve symptoms and control ventricular rate in atrial fibrillation, but it does not have a mortality benefit or significantly delay the progression of heart failure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Empagliflozin, although primarily an anti-diabetic medication, has been shown to significantly benefit patients with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF) by delaying the progression of the disease through its effects on diuresis, myocardial metabolism, and cardiac remodeling.

questions.text:
Order in which the following heart sounds are heard from superior to inferior on the left side chest wall? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

1.Pulmonary area

2.Erb’s area

3.Mitral area
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1 → 2 → 3

 

The heart sounds are heard in the following order from superior to inferior on the left side chest wall:

 

Pulmonary area: 2nd intercostal space near the sternum →Erb’s area (2nd aortic area): 3rd intercostal space near the sternum → Mitral area: 4th intercostal space at the midclavicular line (away from sternum).


Educational Objective:

 

The correct order from superior to inferior for heart sounds on the left side chest wall is pulmonary area, Erb’s area, and mitral area.

questions.text: A patient presents with a pansystolic murmur and features of carditis. Echocardiography showed mitral regurgitation. Which of the following is the most common manifestation of this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Arthritis

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical presentation suggests acute rheumatic fever (ARF), which often presents with carditis as one of the major manifestations. In ARF, the most common manifestation is arthritis, which is typically a migratory polyarthritis affecting large joints such as the knees, ankles, elbows, and wrists. This arthritis responds well to nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Chorea: This is also a manifestation of ARF but is less common than arthritis.

 

Option C. Erythema marginatum: This is a characteristic rash seen in ARF but is less common than arthritis.

 

Option D. Subcutaneous nodules: These are also seen in ARF but are much less common than arthritis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In acute rheumatic fever, arthritis is the most common manifestation, typically presenting as migratory polyarthritis that responds well to NSAIDs.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding Nutritional Rickets? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Urine Ca ratio > 0.15

 

Nutritional rickets is a disorder caused by vitamin D deficiency, leading to impaired bone mineralization and growth. The incorrect statement in the context of nutritional rickets is:

 

This is typically seen in primary hyperparathyroidism, not in secondary hyperparathyroidism like that seen in vitamin D deficiency or nutritional rickets. In nutritional rickets, the urine calcium-to-creatinine ratio is usually low because of the body's attempt to conserve calcium.

 

Other Options:

 

The following points summarize the key biochemical features of nutritional rickets:

 

Option A. Normal Calcium: In many cases of nutritional rickets, serum calcium levels are normal or low-normal at the time of presentation due to secondary hyperparathyroidism, which compensates for the low calcium by increasing parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels.

 

Option B. Low Phosphate: Hypophosphatemia is common in rickets due to decreased intestinal absorption of phosphate and increased renal excretion.

 

Option D. High PTH: Secondary hyperparathyroidism occurs as a response to hypocalcemia, leading to elevated PTH levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In nutritional rickets, the urine calcium-to-creatinine ratio is typically low, not high. Elevated PTH, low phosphate, and normal calcium levels are typical biochemical findings in this condition.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient presented to the hospital with palpitations. Physical examination showed a diastolic murmur in the left 3rd intercostal space. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Aortic regurgitation

 

The presence of a diastolic murmur heard best at the left 3rd intercostal space (Erb's point) is characteristic of aortic regurgitation. Aortic regurgitation occurs when the aortic valve does not close properly, allowing blood to flow back into the left ventricle during diastole.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aortic stenosis: This condition produces a systolic ejection murmur, typically heard at the right second intercostal space.

 

Option C. Mitral regurgitation: This condition causes a pansystolic murmur heard best at the apex of the heart and radiates to the axilla.

 

Option D. Tricuspid regurgitation: This condition causes a pansystolic murmur heard best at the lower left sternal border.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aortic Regurgitation is associated with a diastolic murmur, best heard at Erb’s point (left 3rd intercostal space). The murmur is typically described as a high-pitched, blowing, decrescendo murmur.

questions.text: A young male patient presents with ptosis and muscle weakness which reportedly worsens in the evening and improves in the morning. This is relieved by neostigmine. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Myasthenia gravis

 

Myasthenia gravis is characterized by fluctuating muscle weakness that worsens with activity and improves with rest. The ptosis and muscle weakness worsening in the evening and improving in the morning, along with improvement with neostigmine (a cholinesterase inhibitor), strongly support the diagnosis of myasthenia gravis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Huntington chorea: Characterized by a triad of dementia, psychiatric manifestations, and chorea movements, which are not present in this patient.

 

Option C. Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS): Involves both upper and lower motor neuron signs, such as atrophied limbs, spasticity, exaggerated deep tendon reflexes, and fasciculations, none of which are described in this case.

 

Option D. External ophthalmoplegia: Refers to weakness of the extraocular muscles without the systemic features seen in myasthenia gravis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fluctuating muscle weakness with diurnal variation and improvement with cholinesterase inhibitors are hallmark features of myasthenia gravis.

questions.text: Which of the following murmur increases on standing? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. HOCM

 

The murmur of Hypertrophic Obstructive Cardiomyopathy (HOCM) typically increases on standing. This is due to the decreased venous return and preload that occur with standing, which result in a reduction in the size of the left ventricular cavity. The smaller cavity size exacerbates the outflow obstruction under the aortic valve, thereby intensifying the murmur.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mitral Regurgitation (MR): The murmur associated with MR typically decreases when standing due to the decreased venous return and reduced volume load on the left ventricle, which lessens the regurgitant flow across the mitral valve.

 

Option C. Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD): The murmur of a VSD generally decreases on standing due to reduced left to right shunting caused by decreased venous return.

 

Option D. Mitral Stenosis (MS): The murmur of mitral stenosis also decreases on standing. The reduction in preload lessens the flow through the narrowed mitral valve, subsequently reducing the intensity of the murmur.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Among the options listed, the murmur of Hypertrophic Obstructive Cardiomyopathy is unique in that it increases on standing, due to the specific hemodynamic changes that accentuate the outflow obstruction. This characteristic can be a crucial diagnostic clue in the clinical assessment of murmurs.

 

Reference - Harrison/Physical examination of CVS/Chap 239

choices.text: At least 80g dietary fibre
<5 g salt intake everyday
< 30% of the calories should come from fat

questions.text: A diabetic patient's fasting blood glucose level is found to be 160 mg/dL. What will you advise the patient regarding non-pharmacological management? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) < 30% of the calories should come from fat

 

When advising a diabetic patient on non-pharmacological management, it is essential to focus on dietary and lifestyle modifications that can help control blood glucose levels and reduce cardiovascular risk.

 

It is advisable for less than 30% of daily caloric intake to come from fat, with saturated fat being less than 10% and avoiding trans fats altogether. This recommendation helps in managing cholesterol levels and reducing cardiovascular risk.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. At least 80g dietary fibre: The recommended daily intake of dietary fiber is 25 to 40 grams, not 80 grams. High fiber intake helps in controlling blood sugar levels.

 

Option B. <5 g salt intake everyday: The recommendation for sodium intake is less than 2.3 grams per day, with overall salt intake being less than 5 grams per day.

    

Option D. Cholesterol < 100g: There is no guideline recommending cholesterol intake to be less than 100 grams. Current guidelines focus more on overall fat intake and the types of fats consumed rather than specific cholesterol limits.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For diabetic patients, it is recommended that less than 30% of daily calories come from fat, with saturated fat being less than 10% and trans fats being avoided. This helps in managing blood sugar levels and reducing cardiovascular risks.

questions.text: Which of the following is associated with chronic liver disease? (NEET PG 2014)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency

 

Explanation:

 

Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency is a genetic disorder that significantly predisposes individuals to chronic liver disease, including cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma, as well as pulmonary disorders. It results from mutations in the SERPINA1 gene, leading to the accumulation of abnormal alpha-1 antitrypsin protein in the liver, causing damage and disease over time.

 

Pathophysiology :

 

  • Protein Accumulation: Mutant alpha-1 antitrypsin accumulates in the liver's endoplasmic reticulum, impairing liver function.
  • Genetic Origin: Autosomal recessive inheritance from the SERPINA1 gene on chromosome 14.
  • Impact on Liver: Chronic liver disease, cirrhosis, and increased risk of hepatocellular carcinoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hepatitis A: Typically causes acute, not chronic liver disease.

 

Option B. Chronic malaria: Primarily affects the spleen and red blood cells; does not lead to chronic liver disease.

 

Option C. Infectious mononucleosis: Known for causing transient liver enzyme elevations but not chronic liver disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency should be considered in patients with unexplained chronic liver disease and pulmonary symptoms, especially if there is a family history suggestive of this inherited disorder.
